The global production of biobased polymers grows with a staggering average of 42% per year since 2003 and will continue to grow at a high pace. In the course ‘Green Chemistry’ students will learn the (bio)synthetic routes and chemical processes which are currently used for the manufacturing of biobased polymers. All three types of state-of-the-art processes for biopolymers are given: (1) polymerization of biochemicals obtained by pyrolysis or biorefinery of organic material, (2) polymerization of biochemicals obtained by fermentation, and (3) biosynthesis of bacterial and plant polymers and their refinery and chemical modification. For each route, examples are given which are state-of-the art. Technological challenges are presented and discussed. All bioplastics which are significant in the global economy are topic in these lectures: PLA, Biobased PE, PEF, PHA, modified starch and cellulose, and other green polymers.

Why does one study English? The short answer is to communicate. However, although many students have studied English for several years, they have not achieved the ability to meaningfully communicate in the language. As English becomes a growing lingua franca, those who can use English effectively will gain many new opportunities. This course is designed for students who want to expand their ability to use English in a variety of situations. Emphasis will be on spoken communication, although some aspects of written and nonverbal cues will be examined, as well. Students will be taught to develop competence in natural conversation through role-play and small and large group discussions. Additional speaking activities will include debates and group presentations. Students will be assigned tasks to be solved using English collaboratively, just as they may need to do in situations outside of a classroom. Speaking activities will focus on relevant and topical issues, such as cultural figures, social conventions, comparing cultures, news and events, and entertainment, which will be drawn from experience and texts. Students should expect to be pushed outside of their comfort zone in order to develop fluency, automaticity, and confidence in using English for meaningful communication and to be able to continue to use it after the course ends.

In this integrated skills course, students will develop fluency, accuracy, and communication skills in order to gain confidence in a variety of English-speaking business situations. There is an emphasis on speaking, especially impromptu situations. Writing for various business purposes, such as professional emails, CVs, and application forms, will be practiced. Essential business vocabulary will also be introduced through business-related readings. Participants will develop useful skills, cultural awareness, and vocabulary through active participation in everyday business situations.

What do Americans eat and how is that food produced? The United States food industry is a complex system of diverse businesses that provides plentiful, relatively inexpensive food. The food system shapes the eating choices, cultural identities, and health of Americans. Since the early 20th century, government has taken a strong interest in regulating and monitoring the production, packaging, distribution, preparation, and sale of foods. This course will present a framework for understanding the US industrial food system, analyze its sustainability, identify issues about safety, quality, and equity, and discuss government policies related to the safety and distribution of food.

课程内容包括:光学分析法，电子显微分析技术、热分析方法、色谱和质谱分析法、电化学分析法、其他表面分析技术和分析测定中的样品处理技术

Central in this course is the analysis of the unit operations of dairy products produced on a factory scale. Calculations about the process is the main part of these lectures. Students will do small assignments based on a literature study and topics in the given lecture. The results of these assignments are presented and discussed within the group during the lectures in order to create an interacting atmosphere and enhance the learning effects.

Industrial chemistry plays a vital role as an applied science in diverse areas that influence human society, ranging from economic, environmental to political stability. This course explores the relationship between industrial activities and their importance to our society. Students will learn important chemical processes used in industry, ranging from the large-scale production of bulk chemical commodities, industrial gases, petrochemicals and polymers. If time allows, the course will also examine the methods of emulsion formulation in relation to the home care products application.
